Let be an orientable surface in . Then we can consider a normal vector field to . The derivative of at a point gives rise to a linear map from to . But both tangent spaces and correspond to the same subspace of , and so the two can be naturally identified. Thus the derivative of at a point gives rise to a linear operator on , self-adjoint with respect to the inner product on given by the dot product. The operator is called the shape operator.

Intuitively, describes how the normal vectors to vary up to first order around the point . A vector is an eigenvector of if and only if the normal vector, to first order, only varies in the direction of as we travel along a curve on tangent to at .

A Possible Line of Attack

One option that may help us is to consider whether the multilinear restriction theorem holds, under a weaker range of , under weaker curvature assumptions on the linear operator , i.e. that it has rank at least for some fixed . Since Tacy’s argument only requires Stein-Tomas estimates interpolated with transversality estimates, it may be possible to adapt her argument to this more general situation. This may possibly cut down the number of ‘bad caps’ to consider, which may result in better numerology when considering the relevant induction on scales.
